Award.AwardTitle: AF: EAGER: An Algorithmic Framework for Self-Assembly

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Self-assembly is a ubiquitous, natural, robust process in many living organisms and occurs through coordinated action of independent objects/entities leading to the formation of well-defined patterns. For instance, microtubules form a framework for structures such as the spindle apparatus that appears during cell division. A goal of this project is to develop an algorithmic framework to identify the intelligence of encoded patterns in self-assembly systems. Insights gained from this project are important to computational science and engineering in order to develop novel engineered self-assembly systems. The novelty of the algorithmic framework lies in the combination of stochastic discrete event simulations and molecular/cellular level models in cellular automata. This approach will enable the cooperation of multiple discrete events at multiple temporal levels of the self-assembly process to provide precise control of such events that exhibits specific behaviors observed in such systems. A discrete dynamical cellular automata model will be developed to represent the local behavior of interacting tubulin dimers in forming a microtubules lattice.

The research will provide a hybrid algorithmic framework for the wider algorithmic community. Other broader Impacts include multidisciplinary training for students, and integration of research into undergraduate/graduate courses in computer science and mechanical engineering curricula. Outreach activities involve developing and organizing workshops related to self-assembly algorithms and framework. The proposed MTetris game is intended to attract middle and high school students to STEM fields. The results will be disseminated through journal and conference publications and freely available online.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Self-assembly is a ubiquitous, natural and robust process in many living organisms and occurs through a coordinated action of independent objects/entities leading to the formation of well-defined patterns. In this project, we developed an algorithmic framework to identify the intelligence of encoded patterns in self-assembly systems. Our framework allows the exploration of spontaneous emergent behavior at both spatial and temporal scales in microtubule self-assembly. Insights gained from this project are important to biology, computational science and engineering in order to develop novel engineered self-assembly systems.

We established a fundamental framework for stochastic molecular-level simulations of the microtubule fibril formation process that will serve as a basis for analyzing more realistic models with competing pathways in the future. Specifically, we employed a divide-and-conquer approach by dissecting the aggregation process into different phases based on the rates of their aggregation dynamics and modeled them separately using chemical kinetics. The simulation framework is also extendible to seamlessly incorporate other competing pathways of aggregation and other variables into the system and uses a System of Systems (SoS) discrete event simulation paradigm.

We have also used amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide as a model protein aggregation system that is known to form misfolded aggregates in patients suffering from Alzheimer's Disease; this component was added due to the availability of biophysical experimental data to validate our predictions. Our key outcomes include a model identification method, parameter estimation and fine-tuning methods and model-based predictions for the entire aggregation pathway. The model identification method can also incorporate realistic parameters of the microtubule/Aβ systems that affect the aggregation process. The parameter fine-tuning block suggests that there are in fact multiple solutions for the estimated parameters that may motivate new methods to disrupt this pathway for drug discovery or designing novel engineered systems. We also identified a critical stage of this self-assembly process, called the nucleation mass, which serves as the crucial gate-keeper of the entire aggregation dynamics; additionally, we identified the phenomenon of secondary nucleation in the self-assembly process that plays an important role in its dynamics.

Our specific project outcomes include:

1) Development of a chemical kinetics based differential equations based simulation framework that can potentially identify the rate constants involved in the pre- and post-nucleation phases of self-assembly.

2) Development of a generalized stability model for a system of differential equations under perturbation that can fine-tune the estimated parameters. This model suggests that there are in fact multiple solutions of rate constant and nucleation mass combinations each of which fit the experimental data well. Over-all this work can identify a stricter range for nucleation mass as well as the probability of each nucleated oligomer to trigger the post-nucleation pathway. This also identifies the stability of the entire aggregation system and will help in designing new modeling methods to disrupt such pathways for drug discovery.

3) Development of an efficient, flexible SoS simulation paradigm that can effectively characterize the dynamics of microtubule self-assembly as well as other types of nucleation dependent protein aggregation pathways.

4) Design, development and fabrication of a microtubule lattice formation puzzle that can identify the probabilities of formation of each MT lattice structure with varying size and structure. These probabilities were incorporated in a spatial simulation of the self-assembly simulation to identify the rate constants involved therein.


The project findings have been widely disseminated through several publications, presentations and the creation of (i) a new International Workshop on Complex Networks Dynamics: Cross-disciplinary tools for modeling, analysis and design (CoNed 2013) and (ii) a special track on Emerging applications of Molecular and genetic Networks (EmNet 2014-17), held in conjunction with the BICT 2014-17 conference series. Graduate students involved in the project have been trained in both computational approaches and biophysical experimental techniques. These students are well-prepared for pharmaceutical/biotech/programming related jobs in the future.

The project findings were brought into the classroom through the PI's graduate level course on Parallel Programming and undergraduate level Senior Design at Virginia Commonwealth University. This project was also instrumental in supporting some undergraduate students in the PI’s laboratory (for the senior design projects). Thomas Dwyer, a sophomore at VCU, won first place in AIAA: Young Professional Student Education (YPSE) undergraduate research competition in November 2013 for designing a three-dimensional puzzle to mimic microtubule self-assemby and was created using SolidWorks CAD software and a 3D printer. This educational puzzle was introduced to 5th graders at St. Catherine’s School in Richmond to inspire them in the STEM fields.

This project is uniquely poised towards creating an automated diagnostic tool for self-assembly. The project also makes a very important translational impact: our developed framework can be easily extended to create a flexible, plug-and-play based diagnostic software for protein aggregation and misfolding in general and microtubule/amyloid formation in particular that will aid drug discovery and intelligent systems design in the future.


Last Modified: 11/29/2016
Modified by: Preetam Ghosh

In this project, we developed an algorithmic framework to identify the intelligence of encoded patterns in self-assembly systems. Our framework allows the exploration of spontaneous emergent behavior at both spatial and temporal scales in microtubule self-assembly. Insights gained from this project are important to biology, computational science and engineering in order to develop novel engineered self-assembly systems. We established a fundamental framework for stochastic molecular-level simulations of the microtubule fibril formation process that will serve as a basis for analyzing more realistic models with competing pathways in the future. Specifically, we employed a divide-and-conquer approach by dissecting the aggregation process into different phases based on the rates of their aggregation dynamics and modeled them separately using chemical kinetics. The simulation framework is also extendible to seamlessly incorporate other competing pathways of aggregation and other variables into the system and uses a System of Systems (SoS) discrete event simulation paradigm. Our key outcomes include a model identification method, parameter estimation and fine-tuning methods and model-based predictions for the entire aggregation pathway. The parameter fine-tuning block suggests that there are in fact multiple solutions for the estimated parameters that may motivate new methods to disrupt this pathway for drug discovery or designing novel engineered systems. We also identified a critical stage of this self-assembly process, called the nucleation mass, which serves as the crucial gate-keeper of the entire aggregation dynamics; additionally, we identified the phenomenon of secondary nucleation in the self-assembly process that plays an important role in its dynamics. Our specific project outcomes include: 1) Development of a chemical kinetics based differential equations based simulation framework that can potentially identify the rate constants involved in the pre- and post-nucleation phases of self-assembly. 2) Development of a generalized stability model for a system of differential equations under perturbation that can fine-tune the estimated parameters. These probabilities were incorporated in a spatial simulation of the self-assembly simulation to identify the rate constants involved therein. The project findings have been widely disseminated through several publications, presentations and the creation of (i) a new International Workshop on Complex Networks Dynamics: Cross-disciplinary tools for modeling, analysis and design (CoNed 2013) and (ii) a special track on Emerging applications of Molecular and genetic Networks (EmNet 2014-17), held in conjunction with the BICT 2014-17 conference series. These students are well-prepared for pharmaceutical/biotech/programming related jobs in the future. The project findings were brought into the classroom through the PI's graduate level course on Parallel Programming and undergraduate level Senior Design at Virginia Commonwealth University. This project was also instrumental in supporting some undergraduate students in the PI?s laboratory (for the senior design projects). Thomas Dwyer, a sophomore at VCU, won first place in AIAA: Young Professional Student Education (YPSE) undergraduate research competition in November 2013 for designing a three-dimensional puzzle to mimic microtubule self-assemby and was created using SolidWorks CAD software and a 3D printer. This educational puzzle was introduced to 5th graders at St. Catherine?s School in Richmond to inspire them in the STEM fields. This project is uniquely poised towards creating an automated diagnostic tool for self-assembly. The project also makes a very important translational impact: our developed framework can be easily extended to create a flexible, plug-and-play based diagnostic software for protein aggregation and misfolding in general and microtubule/amyloid formation in particular that will aid drug discovery and intelligent systems design in the future.
